BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 10, 1913.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MARCH IN HONOR OF WILSON

RUDOLF EUCKEN TO LECTURE

THE SENIORS FEAST ON WIT

U. S. SHIPS MUST PAY TOLLS

More Than One Hundred Hopkins Students Take Part in Inaugural Parade.
They Made a Fine Showing.

Noted German Philosopher Will Deliver
Lectures in English and in German
Here This Week.

Many Clever Speeches as Well as an
Excellent Menu—Edmund S.
Donoho Toastmaster.

Juniors Win Debate on Question of
Panama Canal Tolls by Unanimous
Vote—Uhler Gets Adams Medal.

More than one hundred strong,
the Johns Hopkins delegation to the
Woodrow Wilson inaugural parade,
after a tedious wait of nearly four
hours, finally got under way just
as twilight was fast coming on. The
Hopkins paraders advanced in true
military fashion and seemed to be
by far the best drilled of any of the
,
college divisions.
The Black and Blue contingent
was led by Freddie Lee, who was
chie,f marshal. He was assisted by
Walter D. Sutton, Jack Fulton,
Blanchard Randall and C. Leland
Getz. The big Hopkins standards
were carried by George Y. Rusk
and Thomas S. Poole.
From the moment the Hopkins
marchers fell in line until ranks
were broken at the end of the parade, they were warmly applauded
along the entire route of the parade.
By the time the Hopkins division
reached President Wilson's reviewing stand it was almost dark. Although, because of the darkness, the
Hopkins marchers did not show up
quite as well as they would have
done by daylight, nevertheless,
President Wilson seemed to be
greatly pleased by the fine turn-out
made by Hopkins.
The majority of the Hopkins paraders left for Washington on the
"Hopkins Special," which pulled out
of Union Station about 8.45 A. M.
After reaching Washington and
marching to the place where they
were to assemble in the afternoon,
the members of the party dispersed.
Some went to the capitol and waited
until President Wilson took his oath
of office and delivered his inaugural
address; others went sight-seeing.
Shortly after two o'clock the Hopkins marchers assembled and began
rather impatiently to wait for the
signal to start. Numerous false
alarms were given from time to
time, and the hopes of getting under
way were dashed to the ground.
Many of the Hopkins paraders
looked up old friends in the ranks
of the Princeton and University
of Virginia delegations. A little
altercation with an old man in regard to standing on his lawn to view
the parade helped to liven up things.
Through some peculiar arrangement the University of Virginia
delegation had its band march behind it instead of in front. This
band, which was of the co-ed variety, was the cause of considerable
merriment. Virginia seemed to be
anxious to wish it on Hopkins and
Hopkins refused to annex it. The

As announced in THE NEwsLETTER of January 27, Rudolf
Eucken, professor of philosophy at
the University of Jena, will deliver
two lectures here this week. On
Monday, March io, Professor Eucken will lecture in English on the
subject of "Philosophy and Religion," at 5 P. M.; and, at 8 P. M.,
on Tuesday the 11th, he will supplement this first lecture by one in
German on the subject of "Presentday Conflicts for the Worth of Human Life." Both of these subjects
give free play to the wonderful
wealth of thoroughly mastered and
assimilated learning that he has at
his command.
For those who have not as yet
made the acquaintance of Professor Eucken through their study of
philosophy, THE NEWS-LETTER Will
try briefly to state the chief points
of his idealistic philosophy.
Eucken is the recognized exponent
and the principal leader of the
movement of thought known as
vitalistic idealism. We will quote
from our own pages (No. 14):
"Very few of those who are properly informed will dispute the assertion that to Eucken, more than
to any other one man, belongs the
credit of having successfully counteracted the poisonous influence of
the naturalism of Hegel, the pessimism of Schopenhauer, the positivism of Comte, and the subjective
emotionalism of Nietzsche, and of
substituting in the place of these
misleading philosophicalspeculations
a Christian Weltanshauung." The
distinctive feature of Eucken's philosophy constitutes an answer to the
question: "How are we to find the
right course of conduct, in order
that, by following it, we may gain
the truth, the reality, the higher
life?" Thomas Seltzer writes that
Eucken teaches that "there is evil
in the world that has to be overcome, and, hence life is a fight, a
conflict, a struggle to overcome the
evil and develop the good." Man
must learn to turn away from what
is merely animal and free himself
from nature and from the material.
When he does this, he begins to live
the spiritual life, which "is the sole
reality of the world." In developing the spiritual life, man also acquires immortality. Eucken, therefore, grants immortality only to
those who have freed themselves
from the temporal and attained the
spiritual life. Religion, therefore,
quite naturally holds a prominent
place in Eucken's philosophy. Chris-

The senior class held its annual
banquet o n Thursday evening,
March 6, at the Hotel Emerson.
The occasion was, without doubt,
a success, as all those present can
and will testify and, although, possibly not so uproarious as the last
banquet was, nevertheless, far more
enjoyable.
After dinner a vote was taken to
find out the opinion of the class
upon the stars in various lines who
were members of the class. Mr.
Gillet was voted the most popular
and the best athlete; Mr. Donoho,
the handsomest; Mr. Getz, as the
member who had done most for
Hopkins and the man most likely
to succeed; Mr. Wolman, the wittiest; Mr. Marshall, the most rustic;
Mr. Sattler, the most optimistic;
Mr. Marston, the greatest ladies'
man; Mr. Ray, the most dignified;
Mr. Dickinson, the brightest and
most eccentric man; Mr. Penniman,
as the class shark (especially in
German), etc. After the voting had been completed, Mr. Edmund S. Donoho rose
to introduce the speakers of the
evening. The first toast was:"Four
Years of 1913," by C. Leland Getz,
president of the class. The following toasts were then given: "Athletics," J. A. "Dewey" Penniman;
"Our Hullabaloo," Julian D. Sears;
"Witticisms by Dunlap," F. Merrill
Hildebrandt; "Musical Clubs,"
Emory H. Niles;"Dean vs. Tango;"
A. Gus Sattler. After the regular
speeches several informal addresses
were made, chief of which was a
mimicking of all the members of
the class by Mr. Gillet.
The committee in charge of the
banquet was composed of the following: George M. Gillet, Jr.,
chairman; G. Ellis Porter; Julian
H. Marshall; Louis L. Jacobs; J.
Edward Richardson, Jr., C. Leland
Getz.

(Continued on page 8, col. 2.)

A crowd of moderate size turned
out on Friday evening to hear the
annual interclass debate and public
speaking contest; nor was the audience distinguished by any degree
of enthusiasm. The speaking contest was an excellent one, as has
been the case with the greater number of these contests in the last two
or three years. The decision was
awarded by the judges—Prof. D.
M. Robinson, Prof. W. D. Mustard
and Mr. Lawrence C. Wroth—to
Claude I. Uhler for his delivery of
Henry W. Grady's speech on "The
Southern Negro." His voice was
even and clear and nothing was
overdone. Practically the same remark holds true for the other contestants—Millard Eiseman, Moses
Barroway and Charles S. Weech.
The last two had unusually powerful
voices and, perhaps, relied too much
on these to carry them over places
where a simple, straight-forward
declamation, without any attempt at
dramatic delivery, would have been
more effective. Eiseman was somewhat more successful in this respect.
After the Musical Clubs rendered
a selection, Dr. French, as presiding officer, announced the rules of
the debate. The juniors had the
affirmative of the question: "Resolved, That without regard to the
obligations of the Hay-Pauncefote
treaty the tolls of the Panama
Canal should be the same for the
merchant vessels of all nations. It
is understood that the term 'all nations' includes the United States of
America." Hanunond, a s first
speaker for the affirmative, sought
to establish the fundamental propositions on which their debate rested.
Simpson elaborated these arguments
and refuted one or two statements
the first speaker on the negative
side, M. H. Waxman, had made.
Getz brought the prepared speeches
to a close. The affirmative restricted their speeches to a few telling
points which they Grove home at
every opportunity; whereas, the
negative scattered its fire somewhat,.
bringing in a variety of questions
that had better been left untouched.
The rebuttal speeches were well delivered, with the exception of a few
diverting instances of mispronunciation.
As a whole, the debate was not
equal to those of recent years. The
question, being a hypothetical one,
may have been partially responsible
for this. But neither side confined
itself strictly to the question at issue
and broached matters of ship sub-

The junior banquet will take place
immediately after the Easter holidays; the exact date and place will
be announced later. The banquet
committee is: Walter Geissel, chairman; Richard Coblentz; Lawrence
Getz.

At the last meeting of the Engineering Society, which was held on
March 3, the speaker was Professor
Bliss. He gave a splendid lecture
on "The Advantage of Other Than
Technical Subjects in the Education
of an Engineer." The attendance
was large. No more meetings of
the society will be held until after
the Easter holidays.

The Medical Standard Book CO.
307 N. CHARLES STREET

The assistant of J. E. Greiner,
consulting engineer, is William W.
Pagan, A. B. '05, M. E. at Massachusetts "Tech."
George W. Field, associate professor 1893-96, is chief game warden of Massachusetts, where he is
doing splendid work in the the preservation of the game.
Dr. Benjamin T. Terry, M. D.
'04, is no longer at the Rockefeller
Institute for Research, but at the
Pathological Laboratories, King's
County Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y.
Henry 0. Thompson, A. B. '87,
will become once more a member of
the firm of Harris & Thompson,
with the expiration of the term of
Mr. Harris as Postmaster of Baltimore.
Henry McE. Knower, fellow in
anatomy '96, is professor of anatomy at the University of Cleveland,
which, he announces with pride, is
the only university owned and run
by a city.
Philip R. Moale, Ph. D. in chemistry '94, has given up his chemistry and has taken up insurance and
real estate in his home town, Asheville, N. C. He is said to be doing
very well.
On the first of this month James
Morfit Mullen, A. B. '99, a former
Hopkins track star, gave up his connection with the law firm of Gans
& Haman and opened his own office
in the Gaither Building.
John S. Billings, A. B. '89, is
making a splendid reputation in
New York in connection with the
State Board of Health. Mr. Billings received his M. D. at the University of Pennsylvania in 1892.
Among the 5,000 volumes on agriculture recently donated to Cornell is a history of rare plants, written by Clusius and published in
1583, together with a volume by
George Washington, published in
1803.
As a means of encouraging scholarship, aside from Phi Beta Kappa,
Miami is to organize a scholarship
club. It is hoped to make membership in the club one of the big
honors of college. All men coming
up to the general average of "B"
will be eligible to membership.
The engagement has been announced of David D. Leib, Ph. D.
'09, who is at present teaching
mathematics at Yale, to Miss Hazel
Patten of Baltimore. Miss Patten
is an instructor in zoology at the
Western High School of this city,
and is a graduate of Goucher College. The marriage will take place
some time in June.
The University of Michigan recently staged a two-act farce presented by the Chinese Students'
Club of the university the play itself being an original production of
two of the members of the club.
A report states that twenty different nationalities were in the audience, all of whom enjoyed the Oriental production.

Dr. Buchner's Contribution.

Dr. Edward F. Buchner, professor of education and philosophy in
this University, publishes in this
month's Atlantic Educational Journal an article entitled "Maryland's
Educational Position in 1910." The
facts for this article he culled from
the report of the Russell Sage
Foundation, which has just compiled statistics about the public
school systems in the various States.
Maryland, according to Dr. Buchner's article, ranks eighteenth in
the average annual salary of public school teachers; thirty-third in
school mortality—for 1,000 pupils
in elementary schools there are 47
in high schools; thirty-fifth in the
annual current expenditures for
each child of school age; forty-first
in the per cent, of the school population enrolled in public and private
schools. Maryland is one of the
twelve States which does not have
compulsory attendance throughout
the State, and is one of the twentynine States that have neither mandatory nor permissive laws relative
to the medical inspection of schools.
Taking all in all, Maryland, as a
whole, is presented as occupying
the thirty-sixth rank among the
forty-eight States.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 10, 1913.

Owing to the prolonged illness of
the editor-in-chief, THE NEWS-LETTER is being edited by a member of
the Board.

Spring Athletics.

The spring teams at college are
unusually promising this year. Candidates are many and good. The
freshman class, especially, h a s
shown persistent spirit in supporting the teams with a will. It would
seem that the lacrosse team has another championship year ahead,
while baseball is even more promising than last year. However, one
of the most gratifying things about
spring athletics has been the excellent showing of the track team.
We think of the teams gone by as
composed of giants possessed of
lightning speed and great endurance. No doubt they were unusual,
but in this year's team we have men
to match them. The mile relay is
the best that we ever had, and
other records have been broken, and
some more will be lowered before
the season is over.
The schedule ahead is promising:

A Plea to the Homewood Committee.

With the completion of the plans
for the new buildings of the University, definite lines will be established by which the University must
abide for some time.
Activities will thrive on the one
hand if space is allowed for their
growth; on the other hand, they
will die if provision is not made for
their accommodation. We understand that provision has been made
for a NEWS-LETTER office and for
several other offices of like character, but as yet we have heard
nothing in reference to the Grotius
Society. The Grotius Society is
not a class fostered by the University' as a sideline in teaching, but
it is a literary and debating society,
which, although it has been through
many vicissitudes, has now come to
a position of stability. It is supported by at least one-third of •the
undergraduates; its weekly meeting
is attended by an average of twenty
men. Is it reasonable to suppose that
an established institution of this kind
will grow in new and better surroundings. In the larger colleges
literary societies hold places of respect and even eminence. They
have their meetings in a private
auditorium, have well-fitted rooms

Alas! for the subtle.influences of
men's words. We have still another example in the happenings of
last Friday evening. The debate
was proceeding merrily with Mr. C.
Leland Getz staunchly holding
forth. His words were running like
scoriac rivers. The audience sat
aghast. In the rear of McCoy Hall
a young lady was seen to suddenly
sink backward. Her head fell to
the back of the chair and her eyes
closed. One professor and many
young students rushed to the rescue.
Had she fainted? Had the strain
been too great? Did those burning
words overcome her?
The poetaster of THE NEWSLETTER Board has been wrung to
the very heart by the occasion and
he bursts forth as follows:
Brave Leland held the main,
Old '14 stood at bay,
His words they fell like rain
Which clears the dust away.
His hearers .held their breath,
As long as they did dare.
(One young lady had entirely neglected
her respiratory organs, and)
It was for her like death;
Her head fell on her chair.
Ten gallants hasty rise
*To fetch the fainting fairy forth,
Each one hasty to her hies
To carry her out the door-th.
This was their sure intent,
But the lady—only snuz!
(She must have imagined that they
were sonorous words instead of fiery
ones, and)
So on and on dear Lelie went,
.
So back, so back the gallants guz.

The "turn in orders now" sign
has been removed from the postoffice window. It has served its
purpose, namely, to give us a more
definite idea of the number in demand. Each book will cost us
about four times the selling price,
and owing to the small number that
can possibly be sold and the heavy
fixed expenses per volume for better paper, cover, etc., increased production cannot reduce the cost to
us below the price at which the
book is sold. We cannot afford to
sell many volumes at a sacrifice and
thus the supply will be strictly limited, not greatly to exceed the actual
number of orders already in. Even
now many pages are set up in type
ready for the press.
Now we come to the arrangement
of material. First, a large portion
of the advertising sections are to be
printed up. Next in succession the
individual histories and write-ups
must go to press and then on
through the class histories, athletics,
to the end. The printer demands at
least two months for the issue of
the book, six weeks in the printing
office and two weeks at the bindery.
Now as to the biographies, how
many additions will be made from
now to the end of the year? Very
few, I can assure you. And as for
an inferred rebellion on the part of
the members of the class, I can
brand that idea of the "individual"
as "preposterous" and utter "nonsense"—the class understands the
position of those in charge thoroughly, I hope, and is supporting us
accordingly. The winners of the
P B K keys will not be announced
in time to go into the individual biographies, but the list will be printed in the last section to go to press.
The winners of honorson the spring
teams are not announced usually
until commencement, or even afterwards, as Was the case last year.
The articles on the spring teams
with their write-ups will be fairly
accurate. Thus, I believe, all will
agree that the honors will be heralded abroad as fully as possible without having the staff take a summer
course on Hullabaloo publication.
Now, as to our aims. We, in
charge, of all persons, must assuredly want our Hullabaloo to be

to be. We are getting out. the book

into the book and we are not selling it to make money. We are trying to fill a NEED, as well as to get

and to which we can look back with
pride in years to come. We realize
that we are setting a precedent for

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 10, 1913.
SWIM AGAINST CITY COLLEGE

PICK A JOB IN THE LABORATORY
Noted Psychologist Tells of Science
Which Solves the Problem of "What
Vocation?" Experimentally.

Dr. Hugo Munsterberg, professor
of psychology at Harvard and a
leader in the study of social and
labor problems, explained on Friday
how good motormen and telephone
girls could be picked out by laboratory methods. Psychotechniques—
a sub-science of psychology—makes
the determination. The manner of
selection seems rather simple:
"Twenty motormen of one of our
large cities," said the famous student, "were put to test in our Harvard laboratories, and in several
minutes we were able to pick out
the good motormen, I mean those
who had few accidents, and the bad
ones, those who were continually
causing trouble for their employers
by careless operating of •their cars.
"The test we put them to would
perhaps appear childlike, but it succeeded. We had a table with red
and black cubes on it which epr esented pedestrians a n d vehicles.
Two parallel lines represented a
track, and we had a small car that
could be moved by turning a little
crank. We allowed each motorman
to run the car. At times we pushed
cubes representing automobiles or
persons in front of the car. If the
impulse of the motorman was safe
and his attention careful, he avoided
a collision. A careless operator
would hit the blocks, and the very
men who had had accidents while
running cars on the streets, and we
were able to pick out the reliable
ones.
"If the company employing the
men had known these facts before
employing them, some of the accidents on the line could have been
averted."
Dr. Munsterberg also explained
how he had examined thirty girls
from a telephone operating school.
They were put to tests of accuracy,
attention, impulse and imagination.
Averages were computed, and the
girls continued their schooling.
Some time later, when they had
finished the training, those who had
been dismissed as incapable operators were the same as those Dr.
Munsterberg had found inefficient
in his tests. Each test required fifty
minutes. The schooling required a
year, and the girls who had attended the school had been paid by the
company. If psychotechniqueg, the
science of vocational guidance, had
been employed, contended Dr.
Munsterberg, the company would
have saved the money paid to the
girls while learning and the girls
would have been able to put the
time wasted on some vocation for
which they were fitted.
Following closely the movement
of scientific management, came that
of vocational guidance. Bureaus
have been established in a few
places, where men are examined before being employed.

Freshmen-Sophomores Combine to Form
a Team—Match Takes Place at
Friends School March 19.

The first try-outs for the sophomore - freshman swimming team,
which is to meet the Baltimore City
College on March 19, at the Y. M.
C. A., were held on Friday in the
Friends School pool. About fifteen
men reported, and practiced for the
events in which they wished to compete. The list of events follows :
zoo-yard Relay—Eiseman, Penniman, Beck, Rowland, Branham,
Primrose, Tinges,Woodward, Melamet, Wood, Nicholson and Voshell„
50-yard—Rowland,Eiseman,Beck
and Tinges.
loo-yard — Penniman, Wood,
Fseman, Woodward and Branham.
200-yard--Nicholson, Poole, De
Witt, Smith and Beck.
50-yard Back Stroke -- Eiseman
and Beck.
50-yard Breast Stroke—Rowland,
Penniman, Baer,Eiseman and Primrose.
Plunge—Eiseman,Primrose, Penniman and De Witt.
Fancy Diving—Johnson and Melamet.
The water polo team will also be
picked from these men.
At the meeting held in the Trophy
Room on Wednesday, those in attendance voted to have Branham,
'15, and Woodward, '16, who have
so far arranged the meet, continue
in charge of the team. They will
confer with Manager Hargreaves of
th?. City College in the next few
days and decide on the officials for
the meet. All other details have
been arranged.
On paper the two teams appear
almost evenly matched. The Collegians have the advantage in the
back stroke and fancy diving, but
they are far outclassed by our men
in the breast stroke and plunge.
The action of the two classes in
getting together is highly commendable. Not only are they promoting
interest in a sport which, though
one of the most beneficial', has been
entirely disregarded at Hopkins,
but they are also doing the greater
work of furthering the proper feeling between the members of the
two classes.

[The writer of the editorial to which
Mr. Richardson refers in the foregoing
letter, before writing the editorial, spoke
to several members of the Hullabaloo
Board about the necessity of putting off
the publication of the Hullabaloo as long
as possible in order that every member
of the class be given an opportunity to
put in as much of his biography as possible. Time and again the writer was
put off with some such vague answer as,
"The book will sell better if published
early" or "we'll do the best we can."
He realized •that sufficient thought had
not been given to the subject by the editors of the Hullabaloo. The object of
the editorial was to arouse the board
to a sense of the importance of the
subject and to extract from it, if possible, a definite pledge that the Hullabaloo would be held up as long as possible.
From Mr. Richardson's letter it seems
certain that the two objects of the editor
have been realized, and we wish to
thank Mr. Richardson for so promptly
complying with our wishes.—En.]

More Than One Hundred Hopkins Students Take Part in Inaugural Parade.
They Made a Fine Showing.

Noted German Philosopher Will Deliver
Lectures in English and in German
Here This Week.

Many Clever Speeches as Well as an
Excellent Menu—Edmund S.
Donoho Toastmaster.

Juniors Win Debate on Question of
Panama Canal Tolls by Unanimous

More than one hundred strong,
the Johns Hopkins delegation to the
Woodrow Wilson inaugural parade,
after a tedious wait of nearly four
hours, finally got under way just
as twilight was fast coming on. The
Hopkins paraders advanced in true
military fashion and seemed to be
by far the best drilled of any of the
,
college divisions.
The Black and Blue contingent
was led by Freddie Lee, who was
chie,f marshal. He was assisted by
Walter D. Sutton, Jack Fulton,
Blanchard Randall and C. Leland
Getz. The big Hopkins standards
were carried by George Y. Rusk
and Thomas S. Poole.
From the moment the Hopkins
marchers fell in line until ranks
were broken at the end of the parade, they were warmly applauded
along the entire route of the parade.
By the time the Hopkins division
reached President Wilson's reviewing stand it was almost dark. Although, because of the darkness, the
Hopkins marchers did not show up
quite as well as they would have
done by daylight, nevertheless,
President Wilson seemed to be
greatly pleased by the fine turn-out
made by Hopkins.
The majority of the Hopkins paraders left for Washington on the
"Hopkins Special," which pulled out
of Union Station about 8.45 A. M.
After reaching Washington and
marching to the place where they
were to assemble in the afternoon,
the members of the party dispersed.
Some went to the capitol and waited
until President Wilson took his oath
of office and delivered his inaugural
address; others went sight-seeing.
Shortly after two o'clock the Hopkins marchers assembled and began
rather impatiently to wait for the
signal to start. Numerous false
alarms were given from time to
time, and the hopes of getting under
way were dashed to the ground.
Many of the Hopkins paraders
looked up old friends in the ranks
of the Princeton and University
of Virginia delegations. A little
altercation with an old man in regard to standing on his lawn to view
the parade helped to liven up things.
Through some peculiar arrangement the University of Virginia
delegation had its band march behind it instead of in front. This
band, which was of the co-ed variety, was the cause of considerable
merriment. Virginia seemed to be
anxious to wish it on Hopkins and
Hopkins refused to annex it. The

As announced in THE NEwsLETTER of January 27, Rudolf
Eucken, professor of philosophy at
the University of Jena, will deliver
two lectures here this week. On
Monday, March io, Professor Eucken will lecture in English on the
subject of "Philosophy and Religion," at 5 P. M.; and, at 8 P. M.,
on Tuesday the 11th, he will supplement this first lecture by one in
German on the subject of "Presentday Conflicts for the Worth of Human Life." Both of these subjects
give free play to the wonderful
wealth of thoroughly mastered and
assimilated learning that he has at
his command.
For those who have not as yet
made the acquaintance of Professor Eucken through their study of
philosophy, THE NEWS-LETTER Will
try briefly to state the chief points
of his idealistic philosophy.
Eucken is the recognized exponent
and the principal leader of the
movement of thought known as
vitalistic idealism. We will quote
from our own pages (No. 14):
"Very few of those who are properly informed will dispute the assertion that to Eucken, more than
to any other one man, belongs the
credit of having successfully counteracted the poisonous influence of
the naturalism of Hegel, the pessimism of Schopenhauer, the positivism of Comte, and the subjective
emotionalism of Nietzsche, and of
substituting in the place of these
misleading philosophicalspeculations
a Christian Weltanshauung." The
distinctive feature of Eucken's philosophy constitutes an answer to the
question: "How are we to find the
right course of conduct, in order
that, by following it, we may gain
the truth, the reality, the higher
life?" Thomas Seltzer writes that
Eucken teaches that "there is evil
in the world that has to be overcome, and, hence life is a fight, a
conflict, a struggle to overcome the
evil and develop the good." Man
must learn to turn away from what
is merely animal and free himself
from nature and from the material.
When he does this, he begins to live
the spiritual life, which "is the sole
reality of the world." In developing the spiritual life, man also acquires immortality. Eucken, therefore, grants immortality only to
those who have freed themselves
from the temporal and attained the
spiritual life. Religion, therefore,
quite naturally holds a prominent
place in Eucken's philosophy. Chris-

The senior class held its annual
banquet o n Thursday evening,
March 6, at the Hotel Emerson.
The occasion was, without doubt,
a success, as all those present can
and will testify and, although, possibly not so uproarious as the last
banquet was, nevertheless, far more
enjoyable.
After dinner a vote was taken to
find out the opinion of the class
upon the stars in various lines who
were members of the class. Mr.
Gillet was voted the most popular
and the best athlete; Mr. Donoho,
the handsomest; Mr. Getz, as the
member who had done most for
Hopkins and the man most likely
to succeed; Mr. Wolman, the wittiest; Mr. Marshall, the most rustic;
Mr. Sattler, the most optimistic;
Mr. Marston, the greatest ladies'
man; Mr. Ray, the most dignified;
Mr. Dickinson, the brightest and
most eccentric man; Mr. Penniman,
as the class shark (especially in
German), etc. After the voting had been completed, Mr. Edmund S. Donoho rose
to introduce the speakers of the
evening. The first toast was:"Four
Years of 1913," by C. Leland Getz,
president of the class. The following toasts were then given: "Athletics," J. A. "Dewey" Penniman;
"Our Hullabaloo," Julian D. Sears;
"Witticisms by Dunlap," F. Merrill
Hildebrandt; "Musical Clubs,"
Emory H. Niles;"Dean vs. Tango;"
A. Gus Sattler. After the regular
speeches several informal addresses
were made, chief of which was a
mimicking of all the members of
the class by Mr. Gillet.
The committee in charge of the
banquet was composed of the following: George M. Gillet, Jr.,
chairman; G. Ellis Porter; Julian
H. Marshall; Louis L. Jacobs; J.
Edward Richardson, Jr., C. Leland
Getz.

A crowd of moderate size turned
out on Friday evening to hear the
annual interclass debate and public
speaking contest; nor was the audience distinguished by any degree
of enthusiasm. The speaking contest was an excellent one, as has
been the case with the greater number of these contests in the last two
or three years. The decision was
awarded by the judges—Prof. D.
M. Robinson, Prof. W. D. Mustard
and Mr. Lawrence C. Wroth—to
Claude I. Uhler for his delivery of
Henry W. Grady's speech on "The
Southern Negro." His voice was
even and clear and nothing was
overdone. Practically the same remark holds true for the other contestants—Millard Eiseman, Moses
Barroway and Charles S. Weech.
The last two had unusually powerful
voices and, perhaps, relied too much
on these to carry them over places
where a simple, straight-forward
declamation, without any attempt at
dramatic delivery, would have been
more effective. Eiseman was somewhat more successful in this respect.
After the Musical Clubs rendered
a selection, Dr. French, as presiding officer, announced the rules of
the debate. The juniors had the
affirmative of the question: "Resolved, That without regard to the
obligations of the Hay-Pauncefote
treaty the tolls of the Panama
Canal should be the same for the
merchant vessels of all nations. It
is understood that the term 'all nations' includes the United States of
America." Hanunond, a s first
speaker for the affirmative, sought
to establish the fundamental propositions on which their debate rested.
Simpson elaborated these arguments
and refuted one or two statements
the first speaker on the negative
side, M. H. Waxman, had made.
Getz brought the prepared speeches
to a close. The affirmative restricted their speeches to a few telling
points which they Grove home at
every opportunity; whereas, the
negative scattered its fire somewhat,.
bringing in a variety of questions
that had better been left untouched.
The rebuttal speeches were well delivered, with the exception of a few
diverting instances of mispronunciation.
As a whole, the debate was not
equal to those of recent years. The
question, being a hypothetical one,
may have been partially responsible
for this. But neither side confined
itself strictly to the question at issue
and broached matters of ship sub-

immediately after the Easter holidays; the exact date and place will
be announced later. The banquet
committee is: Walter Geissel, chairman; Richard Coblentz; Lawrence
Getz.

At the last meeting of the Engineering Society, which was held on
March 3, the speaker was Professor
Bliss. He gave a splendid lecture
on "The Advantage of Other Than
Technical Subjects in the Education
of an Engineer." The attendance
was large. No more meetings of
the society will be held until after
the Easter holidays.

The assistant of J. E. Greiner,
consulting engineer, is William W.
Pagan, A. B. '05, M. E. at Massachusetts "Tech."
George W. Field, associate professor 1893-96, is chief game warden of Massachusetts, where he is
doing splendid work in the the preservation of the game.
Dr. Benjamin T. Terry, M. D.
'04, is no longer at the Rockefeller
Institute for Research, but at the
Pathological Laboratories, King's
County Hospital, Brooklyn, N. Y.
Henry 0. Thompson, A. B. '87,
will become once more a member of
the firm of Harris & Thompson,
with the expiration of the term of
Mr. Harris as Postmaster of Baltimore.
Henry McE. Knower, fellow in
anatomy '96, is professor of anatomy at the University of Cleveland,
which, he announces with pride, is
the only university owned and run
by a city.
Philip R. Moale, Ph. D. in chemistry '94, has given up his chemistry and has taken up insurance and
real estate in his home town, Asheville, N. C. He is said to be doing
very well.
On the first of this month James
Morfit Mullen, A. B. '99, a former
Hopkins track star, gave up his connection with the law firm of Gans
& Haman and opened his own office
in the Gaither Building.
John S. Billings, A. B. '89, is
making a splendid reputation in
New York in connection with the
State Board of Health. Mr. Billings received his M. D. at the University of Pennsylvania in 1892.
Among the 5,000 volumes on agriculture recently donated to Cornell is a history of rare plants, written by Clusius and published in
1583, together with a volume by
George Washington, published in
1803.
As a means of encouraging scholarship, aside from Phi Beta Kappa,
Miami is to organize a scholarship
club. It is hoped to make membership in the club one of the big
honors of college. All men coming
up to the general average of "B"
will be eligible to membership.
The engagement has been announced of David D. Leib, Ph. D.
'09, who is at present teaching
mathematics at Yale, to Miss Hazel
Patten of Baltimore. Miss Patten
is an instructor in zoology at the
Western High School of this city,
and is a graduate of Goucher College. The marriage will take place
some time in June.
The University of Michigan recently staged a two-act farce presented by the Chinese Students'
Club of the university the play itself being an original production of
two of the members of the club.
A report states that twenty different nationalities were in the audience, all of whom enjoyed the Oriental production.

Dr. Buchner's Contribution.

Dr. Edward F. Buchner, professor of education and philosophy in
this University, publishes in this
month's Atlantic Educational Journal an article entitled "Maryland's
Educational Position in 1910." The
facts for this article he culled from
the report of the Russell Sage
Foundation, which has just compiled statistics about the public
school systems in the various States.
Maryland, according to Dr. Buchner's article, ranks eighteenth in
the average annual salary of public school teachers; thirty-third in
school mortality—for 1,000 pupils
in elementary schools there are 47
in high schools; thirty-fifth in the
annual current expenditures for
each child of school age; forty-first
in the per cent, of the school population enrolled in public and private
schools. Maryland is one of the
twelve States which does not have
compulsory attendance throughout
the State, and is one of the twentynine States that have neither mandatory nor permissive laws relative
to the medical inspection of schools.
Taking all in all, Maryland, as a
whole, is presented as occupying
the thirty-sixth rank among the
forty-eight States.

Spring Athletics.

The spring teams at college are
unusually promising this year. Candidates are many and good. The
freshman class, especially, h a s
shown persistent spirit in supporting the teams with a will. It would
seem that the lacrosse team has another championship year ahead,
while baseball is even more promising than last year. However, one
of the most gratifying things about
spring athletics has been the excellent showing of the track team.
We think of the teams gone by as
composed of giants possessed of
lightning speed and great endurance. No doubt they were unusual,
but in this year's team we have men
to match them. The mile relay is
the best that we ever had, and
other records have been broken, and
some more will be lowered before
the season is over.
The schedule ahead is promising:

A Plea to the Homewood Committee.

With the completion of the plans
for the new buildings of the University, definite lines will be established by which the University must
abide for some time.
Activities will thrive on the one
hand if space is allowed for their
growth; on the other hand, they
will die if provision is not made for
their accommodation. We understand that provision has been made
for a NEWS-LETTER office and for
several other offices of like character, but as yet we have heard
nothing in reference to the Grotius
Society. The Grotius Society is
not a class fostered by the University' as a sideline in teaching, but
it is a literary and debating society,
which, although it has been through
many vicissitudes, has now come to
a position of stability. It is supported by at least one-third of •the
undergraduates; its weekly meeting
is attended by an average of twenty
men. Is it reasonable to suppose that
an established institution of this kind
will grow in new and better surroundings. In the larger colleges
literary societies hold places of respect and even eminence. They
have their meetings in a private
auditorium, have well-fitted rooms

Alas! for the subtle.influences of
men's words. We have still another example in the happenings of
last Friday evening. The debate
was proceeding merrily with Mr. C.
Leland Getz staunchly holding
forth. His words were running like
scoriac rivers. The audience sat
aghast. In the rear of McCoy Hall
a young lady was seen to suddenly
sink backward. Her head fell to
the back of the chair and her eyes
closed. One professor and many
young students rushed to the rescue.
Had she fainted? Had the strain
been too great? Did those burning
words overcome her?
The poetaster of THE NEWSLETTER Board has been wrung to
the very heart by the occasion and
he bursts forth as follows:
Brave Leland held the main,
Old '14 stood at bay,
His words they fell like rain
Which clears the dust away.
His hearers .held their breath,
As long as they did dare.
(One young lady had entirely neglected
her respiratory organs, and)
It was for her like death;
Her head fell on her chair.
Ten gallants hasty rise
*To fetch the fainting fairy forth,
Each one hasty to her hies
To carry her out the door-th.
This was their sure intent,
But the lady—only snuz!
(She must have imagined that they
were sonorous words instead of fiery
ones, and)
So on and on dear Lelie went,
.
So back, so back the gallants guz.

The "turn in orders now" sign

definite idea of the number in demand. Each book will cost us

and owing to the small number that

fixed expenses per volume for better paper, cover, etc., increased production cannot reduce the cost to
us below the price at which the
book is sold. We cannot afford to
sell many volumes at a sacrifice and
thus the supply will be strictly limited, not greatly to exceed the actual
number of orders already in. Even
now many pages are set up in type
ready for the press.
Now we come to the arrangement
of material. First, a large portion
of the advertising sections are to be
printed up. Next in succession the
individual histories and write-ups
must go to press and then on
through the class histories, athletics,
to the end. The printer demands at
least two months for the issue of
the book, six weeks in the printing
office and two weeks at the bindery.
Now as to the biographies, how
many additions will be made from
now to the end of the year? Very
few, I can assure you. And as for
an inferred rebellion on the part of
the members of the class, I can
brand that idea of the "individual"
as "preposterous" and utter "nonsense"—the class understands the
position of those in charge thoroughly, I hope, and is supporting us
accordingly. The winners of the
P B K keys will not be announced
in time to go into the individual biographies, but the list will be printed in the last section to go to press.
The winners of honorson the spring
teams are not announced usually
until commencement, or even afterwards, as Was the case last year.
The articles on the spring teams
with their write-ups will be fairly
accurate. Thus, I believe, all will
agree that the honors will be heralded abroad as fully as possible without having the staff take a summer

charge, of all persons, must assuredly want our Hullabaloo to be

pride in years to come. We realize
that we are setting a precedent for

THE NEWS—LETTER, MARCH 10, 1913.
SWIM AGAINST CITY COLLEGE

PICK A JOB IN THE LABORATORY
Noted Psychologist Tells of Science
Which Solves the Problem of "What
Vocation?" Experimentally.

Dr. Hugo Munsterberg, professor
of psychology at Harvard and a
leader in the study of social and
labor problems, explained on Friday
how good motormen and telephone
girls could be picked out by laboratory methods. Psychotechniques—
a sub-science of psychology—makes
the determination. The manner of
selection seems rather simple:
"Twenty motormen of one of our
large cities," said the famous student, "were put to test in our Harvard laboratories, and in several
minutes we were able to pick out
the good motormen, I mean those
who had few accidents, and the bad
ones, those who were continually
causing trouble for their employers
by careless operating of •their cars.
"The test we put them to would
perhaps appear childlike, but it succeeded. We had a table with red
and black cubes on it which epr esented pedestrians a n d vehicles.
Two parallel lines represented a
track, and we had a small car that
could be moved by turning a little
crank. We allowed each motorman
to run the car. At times we pushed
cubes representing automobiles or
persons in front of the car. If the
impulse of the motorman was safe
and his attention careful, he avoided
a collision. A careless operator
would hit the blocks, and the very
men who had had accidents while
running cars on the streets, and we
were able to pick out the reliable
ones.
"If the company employing the
men had known these facts before
employing them, some of the accidents on the line could have been
averted."
Dr. Munsterberg also explained
how he had examined thirty girls
from a telephone operating school.
They were put to tests of accuracy,
attention, impulse and imagination.
Averages were computed, and the
girls continued their schooling.
Some time later, when they had
finished the training, those who had
been dismissed as incapable operators were the same as those Dr.
Munsterberg had found inefficient
in his tests. Each test required fifty
minutes. The schooling required a
year, and the girls who had attended the school had been paid by the
company. If psychotechniqueg, the
science of vocational guidance, had
been employed, contended Dr.
Munsterberg, the company would
have saved the money paid to the
girls while learning and the girls
would have been able to put the
time wasted on some vocation for
which they were fitted.
Following closely the movement
of scientific management, came that
of vocational guidance. Bureaus
have been established in a few
places, where men are examined before being employed.

Freshmen-Sophomores Combine to Form
a Team—Match Takes Place at
Friends School March 19.

The first try-outs for the sophomore - freshman swimming team,
which is to meet the Baltimore City
College on March 19, at the Y. M.
C. A., were held on Friday in the
Friends School pool. About fifteen
men reported, and practiced for the
events in which they wished to compete. The list of events follows :
zoo-yard Relay—Eiseman, Penniman, Beck, Rowland, Branham,
Primrose, Tinges,Woodward, Melamet, Wood, Nicholson and Voshell„
50-yard—Rowland,Eiseman,Beck
and Tinges.
loo-yard — Penniman, Wood,
Fseman, Woodward and Branham.
200-yard--Nicholson, Poole, De
Witt, Smith and Beck.
50-yard Back Stroke -- Eiseman
and Beck.
50-yard Breast Stroke—Rowland,
Penniman, Baer,Eiseman and Primrose.
Plunge—Eiseman,Primrose, Penniman and De Witt.
Fancy Diving—Johnson and Melamet.
The water polo team will also be
picked from these men.
At the meeting held in the Trophy
Room on Wednesday, those in attendance voted to have Branham,
'15, and Woodward, '16, who have
so far arranged the meet, continue
in charge of the team. They will
confer with Manager Hargreaves of
th?. City College in the next few
days and decide on the officials for
the meet. All other details have
been arranged.
On paper the two teams appear
almost evenly matched. The Collegians have the advantage in the
back stroke and fancy diving, but
they are far outclassed by our men
in the breast stroke and plunge.
The action of the two classes in
getting together is highly commendable. Not only are they promoting
interest in a sport which, though
one of the most beneficial', has been
entirely disregarded at Hopkins,
but they are also doing the greater
work of furthering the proper feeling between the members of the
two classes.

[The writer of the editorial to which
Mr. Richardson refers in the foregoing
letter, before writing the editorial, spoke
to several members of the Hullabaloo
Board about the necessity of putting off
the publication of the Hullabaloo as long
as possible in order that every member
of the class be given an opportunity to
put in as much of his biography as possible. Time and again the writer was
put off with some such vague answer as,
"The book will sell better if published
early" or "we'll do the best we can."
He realized •that sufficient thought had
not been given to the subject by the editors of the Hullabaloo. The object of
the editorial was to arouse the board
to a sense of the importance of the
subject and to extract from it, if possible, a definite pledge that the Hullabaloo would be held up as long as possible.
From Mr. Richardson's letter it seems
certain that the two objects of the editor
have been realized, and we wish to
thank Mr. Richardson for so promptly
complying with our wishes.—En.]
